cap:
On a snowy winter day, a hungry Risuko came to visit Suzuko in her kitchen.

Risuko: "Wow, it smells so good! Suzuko, what are you making?"
Suzuko: "It’s my first time, but I thought I’d try making cookies."

They start preparing right away, but kneading the dough and cutting out shapes turns out to be harder than expected.

Risuko: "Whoa, the dough is sticking! This is tougher than I thought..."
Suzuko: "They’re all different shapes, but I think that makes them unique and warm in their own way..."

However, Suzuko’s kitchen doesn’t have enough heat to bake the cookies until they’re crispy.

Risuko: "Hmm, the fire is too weak. They’re not browning at all."
Suzuko: "Sorry, Risuko. At this rate, winter might be over by the time they’re done."

Jokes aside, the two decide to head to the ‘Magic Oven’ deep in the forest.
It’s a special place known for its strong heat.

Risuko: "This oven should work just fine!"
Suzuko: "With this, we can bake the best cookies. Risuko, can you help add some firewood?"

With the crackling sound of the fire, a sweet aroma spreads throughout the forest. At last, the cookies are perfectly baked.

Risuko: "They look so delicious!"
Suzuko: "I think they turned out well... but how do they taste?"

At last, it’s snack time. The two eagerly taste the cookies while they’re still hot.

Risuko: "Fresh out of the oven! First come, first served!"
Suzuko: "Yes, they taste wonderful. Sweet and happy..."

With their bellies full, the two relax and enjoy the view outside.

Risuko: "The crackling fire and the sound of me munching cookies... the sounds of a happy winter."
Suzuko: "Why do sweet treats taste so much better in the cold air?"

Suzuko starts thinking about their friends in the forest.
She suggests doing something nice for the animals enduring the cold.

Suzuko: "Hey, Risuko. How about hosting a ‘Winter Feast’ for the forest animals?"
Risuko: "Sharing delicious food with everyone sounds amazing!"

And so, the two head out right away to gather ingredients.

They begin by gathering fruit in the forest.

Risuko: "These look perfectly ripe."
Suzuko: "Just don’t take too many."

As they look at the fruit they’ve collected, Risuko’s hands move on their own.

Risuko: "I didn’t eat it, okay? I’m just doing a quality check!"

Suzuko checks the numbers and notices something.

Risuko: "Did it really decrease that much?"
Suzuko: "It did."
Risuko: "Why not think of it as gaining memories instead of losing fruit?"
Suzuko: "That’s the kind of thinking that causes trouble later."

Reflection time arrives along with a mountain of oranges. Suzuko offers one with a smile.

Risuko: "By the time I finish these, my cheeks will be stuffed with oranges..."
Suzuko: "Eat well, and then let’s move on."

The forest market is lively again today.

Risuko: "This round shape... the heavier it is, the more happiness it feels like it holds."
Suzuko: "These will make wonderful cookies."

In the forest, gathering ingredients also means exchanging rumors.

Risuko: "The birds are really excited. Is this... insider info on tasty fruit?"
Suzuko: "Birds make pretty reliable information sources."

The goat shed is filled with the warm scent of freshly milked milk.

Risuko: "Morning milk feels extra special. Adding this should make everything smoother."
Suzuko: "Yes, it’ll add richness and flavor."

The chickens are hard at work from early morning.

Risuko: "These eggs are so shiny!"
Suzuko: "They’re good eggs. I’m looking forward to the beautiful color once they’re baked."

The mice’s home is surprisingly neat and organized.

Risuko: "This inventory management... totally professional! I should learn from them!"
Suzuko: "This bit of acidity will be perfect with the sweet dough."

Bright red apples stand out beautifully against the white snow.

Risuko: "These apples smell so sweet!"
Suzuko: "They really do. An apple pie with these would be amazing."

On the way back with their baskets, their conversation never stops.

Risuko: "Drop it and you lose. Win, and you get a snack."
Suzuko: "Hehe, whether you win or lose, the snacks are already prepared."

On the way to the forest oven kitchen, Risuko shares treats with every animal they meet.
The basket is overflowing with ingredients.

Risuko: "This chestnut! Great shine, great weight! They say one ‘Magic Chestnut’ gives you energy for three days!"
Suzuko: "...This is definitely a winning chestnut."

A special treat for the birds watching from above.

Risuko: "Eat this and your high notes will improve! Probably! Just a feeling!"
Suzuko: "The birds already look ready to sing."

A thank-you delivery for the mice who shared their grapes.

Risuko: "Those grapes earlier were champions! Here’s a thank-you set. Please share nicely!"
Suzuko: "Helping each other seems to improve both flavor and reputation."

Drawn by the aroma, friends gather, each with slightly different intentions.
Tea talk upstairs, romance downstairs. Before anyone notices, the forest becomes two stories tall.

Risuko: "Relaxing time for everyone."
Suzuko: "I don’t know where to look first."

A fox they meet along the way quietly joins the circle.
Perfect posture, perfect distance. Such good manners are rare even in the forest.

Risuko: "Would you like some too, Mr. Fox? You’re so good at waiting politely!"
Suzuko: "Yes, especially the way his front paws are lined up. A model of forest manners."
Fox: "... (Thank you for the meal.)"
Risuko: "See? He said it properly!"
Suzuko: "What exactly did he say, Risuko?"

As they carry the ingredients, goats gather, drawn by the smell.
It seems it won’t end with just ‘a little.’

Risuko: "...Aren’t they eating way too fast?"
Suzuko: "Yes. All I hear is chewing."
Risuko: "Did I misjudge the portion size?"
Suzuko: "By goat standards, this is normal."

The goat likes it so much that it follows them without a word.
Its steps are light, its gaze fixed straight ahead.

Risuko: "Its eyes are glued to the basket..."
Suzuko: "It liked it so much, it missed the chance to go home."

From behind the trees, a large deer watches with great interest.

Risuko: "Oh! Even that big deer is watching. Suzuko, I want the deer to try some too!"
Suzuko: "You’re right. With eyes like that, we can’t not share."

The deer takes a bite and seems completely satisfied.

Risuko: "Look! The deer’s eyes are sparkling!"
Suzuko: "The natural sweetness is a flavor that makes everyone smile."

They arrive at the forest kitchen and begin with the important task of starting the fire.

Risuko: "Alright, I hear the crackling! This fire is the start of delicious magic."
Suzuko: "Let’s gently feed it some air."

As the pot begins to simmer, the deer smiles with anticipation.

Risuko: "Look, the deer is smiling! This smell might reach the deepest part of the forest."
Suzuko: "That’s a full, happy smile."

In front of the bubbling pot, the deer looks unable to wait any longer.

Risuko: "Mr. Deer, your neck is getting closer to the pot! Just a little longer!"
Suzuko: "The smell of freshly cooked food really is the best spice."

At last, it’s time to taste. Looking around, they realize many animals have gathered.

Risuko: "Suzuko, look! Everyone from the forest is here!"
Suzuko: "Oh my, that’s a big responsibility... Yes, it tastes perfect!"

They arrange the finished dishes on the table, and the party begins.

Risuko: "Thanks for waiting! There’s plenty for everyone! Don’t hold back!"
Suzuko: "Food always tastes better when we eat together."

While Suzuko bakes her special apple pie, the mouse already seems full.

Risuko: "How was it, Mr. Mouse?"
Suzuko: "That’s a very full belly. But maybe there’s always room for apple pie."

A slow, peaceful moment for the two.
After the meal, they enjoy roasting marshmallows over the remaining embers.

Risuko: "Slowly... getting them golden brown is the hardest part."
Suzuko: "Yes. The trick is to keep turning them so they don’t burn."

They happily nibble the soft, melted marshmallows together.

Risuko: "Mmm~! They melt in your mouth, sweet like snow."
Suzuko: "They really do. Every last bite today is perfect."

With both their hearts and bellies full, the two rest quietly on the snow.

Risuko: "God of the forest, thank you for the meal. I hope we find more delicious things tomorrow."
Suzuko: "Yes. It’s all thanks to the forest’s blessings and everyone’s smiles."
